content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												You can't change the keybindings. You're stick using the arrow keys, space, A, S, D, left CTRL and right CTRL.It also didn't seem to register my PS4 controller, which works perfectly with other games such as MGSV.Worse yet is that the level design so far has been terrible, and the clunky controls do nothing to help. You automatically grab on to any wall you touch, which would be fine if the game was designed around it. It is not. I constantly found myself grabbing on to random ledges while I was trying to avoid enemies.Speaking of which, there are a lot of enemies to dodge. Not that they really pose any threat, mind you, at least not on Normal difficulty. As long as you're mashing the attack button, S, you're going to be fine. Shielded enemies must be guard broken with a charged attack, though, which really breaks the flow of combat. The graphics are nice, though, I'll give it that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Wow, this game is fantastic. Having played the original NES Strider and the Genesis Strider, I have to say this game is an absolutely fantastic reboot. It has the open-world feel of the original NES classic but with much better level (and graphic) design, and has the quality of color and atmospheric charm of the Genesis version but with far better view instead of the absurdly close-up shots of Strider Hiryu at the benefit of graphical fidelity. Besides that the game is clean and crisp. It's a joy to play and although at first it may seem too easy (there are difficulty options), that's just a nice way to lull you into the fact that this game requires a lot of strategy. While you start with these clunky combos and button-mashing slaying of any of the Kazakh guards you see, their tactics and yours have to evolve to suit the multi-levelled terrain, the new equipment and abilities both you and the enemies get, and your general skill. The better you get, the more the game begins to feel like a brutal ballet where Strider vaults over enemies and cuts everything in his path with effortless grace. The story is far better than that of its originals since now there's not only voice acting but it's actually got a cohesive and tangible plot this time that isn't arbitrarily sending you across the world in a weirdly specific set of locations with little backstory.Overall, this is a very fun game. I really recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												9.5/10 This game is GREAT!  As someone who beat the genesis strider 1 and strider returns, NES Strider, Playstation Strider 2 (Japanese version), and who has been slaying people on MVC1, 2, and 3 ultimate, this is a wonderful game.  It's like the creators looked at the game Moon Diver which was supposed to be the successor to the Strider franchise, and learned from all the mistakes that were made in that title.  Even without ANY powerups, from the get go, Strider feels just as sleek and fine tuned in his handling and controls as he did on any of his previous incarnations including MVC.  Add in all the cool power ups, the button combinations that are needed to traverse levels, and the multitude of secrets waiting for the gamer with an eye for exploration, and you have a wonderful romp in a revamped Strider universe that  pays many nods to the previous games.There are only a few things for which I fault this game.  Firstly, the music is awesome, especially the nod to the NES Egypt Rail Carrier track.  The track is slower and there are trains in the background capturing some of the feel of the original NES content. However, it drops the ball in that there is no level that takes place on a high speed train.  This was an effect that was supremely brought to life on the NES.  With the current technology, it would have been awesome to see how an idea such as this could have been illustrated and also the game mechanics that would have been involved.  Secondly, we are given different color palattes for Strider as mementos from fallen Striders.  This is a cop-out as it would have been much better to actually RESCUE said Striders and have them join Strider's team either as a type of limited subweapon or as an AI controlled ally or as a completely different character that can be swapped out at any save station.  With that said, if there were other playable characters, the idea of Co-op would easily be implementable.  And, considering that Co-op was already a part of Moon Diver, there is really no excuse for there to be a lack of couch Co-op for Strider.Still, that only amounts to a 0.5 point deduction on an awesome game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Story and Characters: 9/10I mean killing the Winds sisters? Instant win. Hired to kill the Grandmaster Meio? Even better. A classic retelling of the core Strider story complete with the classic assassination feeling along with the judgement of self-righteousness. The villains do not disappear after beating them once and pose a threat every step of the way, even during easy mode.Art and Sound: 9/10 The 2D animation does not try to focus on nostalgia which I really prefer rather than relying on old nostalgic feelings for a game. This makes me feel like a new reboot that actually works which is incredibly rare (I'm looking at you Nintendo). It is aesthetically pleasing. The classic Hiryu "HAHHH" attack sound is missing which I will take a point off just for that (pls add it in the future!)Gameplay: 8/10 Some of the directional attacking is a bit clunky. Although overall the games easy to learn keys are nice on the hands. The directional jumps can also interfere with some tricky terrain passes where you have to calculate the amount of time and reflex you have to make a jump etc. So far I enjoy the upgrades to your Cypher which really makes this higher than it should be (you are welcome Capcom)Replayability: 7/10Can get a bit repetitive but worth exploring the other difficulty options while having fully upgraded your Cypher. Although for $15 dollars this is definitely replayable to a point where you will see immersing yourself into it for hours on end.Final Thoughts Overall: 8/10Strider Hiryu is a classic game rebooted not to fit into the "nostalgia" resurgence of this past decade but tells a core retelling of his story, one that vividly explains the struggle of the Strider character. Buy this. You will not be disappointed. Thank you Double Helix and Capcom for bringing us this masterpiece.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Wow. GRIN's Bionic Commando Rearmed is probably my favorite action game of all time, striking the perfect balance of classic 8-bit old school design and modern gameplay conventions into a blended whole that surpasses all prior (and sadly, subsequent) versions of the franchise. Amazingly, Double Helix's recent version of Strider does the exact same thing for the Cyber-Ninja that seemingly had a larger following in the fighting game scene than in his own titles.Now, Strider's not BCR exactly. Some choices seem a smidge ill-fitting at first. Like the Metroidvania "single grand level" concept seems odd when you have such a mobile character who traditionally has gone through disparate locales in his games like a horny teenager goes through tissues, but they pack it with so many devious traps to flip around and baddies to chop up in such a large set of locations you'll never notice once you get going. Besides, it allows for a "just right" amount of item collection and several super-hidden spots concealing bonus costumes and concept art to give players their OCD collector fix. In general, that's probably the best descriptor of the game design as a whole: just right. And it leads a constant cavalcade of classic Capcom chaos! So much so that there's little to actually say about most of the moment ot moment gameplay that wouldn't just spoil the experience if you're interested after seeing the trailers. Like the Matrix, you really can't be told how awesome it is to be Strider Hiryu, you have to experience it for yourself. I for one, highly recommend plunking down the simoleans to give Strider a go. You'll be slicing and dicing through hordes of Russian Cyber-men within seconds, and flipping and ninja-vanishing around deadly traps while reflecting bullets into robots and summoning your holo-panther buddy to tear new holes into old foes for the next 4-9 hours depending on your difficulty and how much you want to collect.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												So I just beat the game.  The best way I can explain my experience is Shadow Complex meets Ninja Gaiden.  The controls are insanely tight.   The sword swings as fast as you can press the attack button.... no waiting on animations. The graphics are vibrant and clean, with lots of pretty flashes of colors that would make any toddler drool in amazement.   The game makes you genuinely feel like you are far more skilled than you really are, mostly because you can move through most of the game without stopping.  Strider is extremely overpowered, but never to the point of feeling invincible.  I loved this game for the most part, though I have to admit that I was disappointed with the lack of weapon choice or any sort of rpg elements.  I understand that they weren't aiming for that, so I don't really hold it against it.   While it's not my favorite metroidvania, it definetly satiates my craving for a new SotN or Super Metroid.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Strider is a steal at $15. I got maybe 8 hours out of it playing on the normal difficulty and had a blast the whole time. For the most part, it does a great job of making you feel like a total badass ninja relentlessly slicing through foe after foe. The platforming is pretty easy as long as you're not going for a 100% completion; once you try to go for everything, you'll have to do some sections where you must freeze enemies in order to make stepping stones. Even then controlling HIryu is a breeze. The running and jumping make for some of the most entertaining movement controls I've seen since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, and it smartly alternates between blistering action and platforming in gracious tandem. Strider Hiryu's latest game is a load of fun while being a great homage to the original. After a while, when you have a full range of abilities and powerups, it's easy to feel overpowered as you mow down the opposition. It's a fun Metroidvania that I wouldn't mind playing again.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Strider was a very fun and enjoyable action side scroller. Filled with beautiful lighting and fast paced fights, it reminded me of the old days of NES and SNES titles like Metroid and Megaman, along with the (of course) previous installments in the Strider franchise. (Which I have not yet gotten a chance to try personally.) I encourage the use of a controller with this game, but those on the keyboard should be able to manage.Liked:-Fun-Fast-Fluid-Metroidvania-Level design (in general*)Disliked:-Stun locks-Poorly designed invisible walls*-Unengaging story-Questionable voice acting-Anti-climatic ending-Saving at the end of the game stops you from going back and collecting everything. Is an option not to save however. (Awesome reward for beating the final boss... /sarcasm)Overall Score: 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Do you like Metroid?Do you like Mega Man X?I do, and this game being the marriage of the two works out very well. Strider plays like a smoother, quicker modern version of how Zero played in Mega Man X4 and X5. The best thing about this game is that very feel; your character can slash enemies 1:1 with how fast you can mash the attack button and it's very satisfying to plow through enemies at a full sprint.The game is somewhat of a free form metroidvania, but only somewhat. Your objectives are given to you marked on a map and you only need to backtrack through one area in order to fight a particular boss. You can find secrets and upgrades by exploring more once you've powered up, but all of the crucial stuff you'll find just by letting the game hold your hand. The fact that the city is technically open to exploration is nice though, and it doesn't slow the pace of the game if you don't let it. Surely going back to grab stuff often serves as a nice break between difficult boss fights.So the gameplay is really solid all around and that's what's important- however you may find that things are lacking in art direction and story. There are a handful of environments to traverse as the city is separated into districts, but each one is blander than the last. Visually, the game doesn't have much personality especially when you consider that the character's mouths don't move during voice acted cutscenes. I'm not a visual designer, but what I think what this game needed was a darker, more dystopian tone rather than the spitshined anime one we got.The story can't be called a disaster because it isn't really there, but what is there feels dissapointing in light of the fact that they actually bothered to animate a few cutscenes and record dialogue. Especially after defeating the final boss, you might find that the complete lack of meaningful exposition or resolution brings down the experience.Overall, an 8/10 with one point deducted for the each of the two paragraphs above. The gamplay style is timeless and I disagree with the majority of people who found this game frustrating. At about 7 hours for my first normal playthrough, it may be most worth it to buy during a 50% sale but it is generally worth it anyway. It's a fun time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12
Product received for free
												Above all else, this is a game for anyone who gets a kick out of precise controls - assuming you have a decent controller to hand. Strider's signature katana arc is in full evidence here, allowing you to let loose a pleasing flurry of attacks or charge up for a longer-range strike. Movement includes an array of somersault jumps and combine with a wall-climbing mechanic that is never too clingy (as such mechanics can sometimes be). Basically, every room of enemies can be a fun, adrenaline-filled dance - and this is just with the basic toolset the game starts with.There's some interesting depth here - you not only get ranged kunai attacks, a short teleporter hop and three extra modes for your sword, but each of these get different effects in combination, giving you plenty of high-energy options to take down even bigger foes with finesse. There's also a chain-based higher damage mode you can get to if you score a high succession of hits - I never popped the achievement for doing this 25 times, but I managed to quickly take down the one boss I had any real trouble by trigging a succession of these, and like everything else in this game's combat, it has the capacity to make you feel like the ultra-badass you probably aren't.Elsewhere, the game can be unexceptional, though not in any significantly detrimental way. This Strider goes full Metroidvania, and while the aforementioned puzzles are great to track down, it lacks the clever item placement of something like Super Metroid (and for better or worse, there's nothing like that game's shine sparking to test your skills/patience). The environments are thoughtfully if visually unspectacular in their construction - though gameplay is on a 2D plane they've done a great job of layering things in the background and foreground, but it can all look a little samey and the series' distinctive cyber-soviet environments seem a little low-key this time round.Enemy design is a similar story - in terms of function they've nailed it (on sight you have a good idea how an encounter is going to go down, and attacks are appropriately telegraphed so you can get on with the business of dodging and obliterating) but the designs don't really stick in your memory. Bosses are a little better on this front, though they're ultimately lifted from earlier games (and they have some over-used chatter before you encounter them).Still, unless you've recently burned yourself out on Metroidvania-esque titles, there's more than enough style and substance in this game. I've owed this one a review for three years now - taken me around this time to actually have a machine that can run it (oddly) - Chris covered for me on thereticule (http://thereticule.com/strider-the-verdict/), but I couldn't resist singing it's praises myself, especially as three years on, it seems to have largely been forgotten. A shame.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Pros-Fun Boss Battles-Great Skill Design-Ran great on my rig-Smooth controls-Not to long or short time wise-crisp modern graphics(not really a graphics guy but this game looks great while running smoothly)Note: I've read reviews where the writer complains about how drab world. I agree it's drab but no because of art direction. Strider really needed better world building behind it to be masterpiece.  Cons-Weak story/world buildingStrider was great fun. The pace of the game makes you feel like an expert warrior. The action is just at the right speed where I have enough time to react while not being a cake walk either.  Another aspect I loved about Strider was the way skills progressed in the game. Each tool had its distinct strength and wasn't overshadowed by new additions to Strider's arsenal. The enemy variety just was right in that non-boss combat did not feel monotonous meaning each enemy required its unique approach for the most part. The boss battles were really the highlight of this game for me. Some boss patterns were easy and others were hard but none of the fights felt gimmicky. I couldn't just stay in one spot and win the battle. Dodging and moving in to attack were the general patterns but each boss fight requires its own approach in executing those actions. The only aspect that I felt Strider lacked was story. I never gained strong sense of connection with Strider. Nobody in the story cared for Strider leaving me with nothing to identify with. I felt like a random guy who did all these awesome things in a world where the Why was never explained. Maybe these feeling are a result of me having never played a Strider game before? I mean it's alright if you don't give the main character a lot of depth because it's a game but if you take that course your world needs to have the depth to support the story your trying to tell.  The story was decent though and game play was more than enough to make up for the story's failings. This game is really great and you shouldn't pass it up if you enjoy action games. At least for me, Strider sets the standard for the modern Metroidvania title.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												I picked up Strider at some point in one of the many bundles I've bought on sale over the years and went in blind. I expected some sort of platformy hack and slash, I ended up with a fairly engaging ninja-themed metroidvania game.As with most metroidvania games, you start out with fairly minimal abilities. Minimal to the point where I was not very impressed at first since I was just spamming the slash attack. Once you get a few power ups though, your combat options open up immensely and it becomes way more engaging. This isn't to say that it's perfect, I found the combat actually got annoying at several points in the game as some enemies were bullet (slash?) sponges no matter which powers you used, to the point where I found myself skipping over a lot of enemies. I also found some enemy types incredibly annoying to fight against due to the fact that they can stunlock you to death in large packs. Sure you could dodge the bullets, but if you mess up even once, a sufficiently large pack will refreeze/stun you as soon as you break out. Aside from those fights though, I found the boss fights to be very fun with varied mechanics.Movement in this game was great, especially as you unlock powers to increase your movement options and unlock new areas. I always felt like I was in control when moving, which is great for combat. My only complaint is that some maps are fairly large and I found myself wishing for a quick way to traverse large flat areas, such as with some sort of charge/sprint power seen in some other games in the genre. I also found it annoying that the dash skill you eventually unlock completely kills your momentum. It's great for giving you more fine control, but it makes traversing through old areas to look for unlocks annoying.

												Normal playthrough: 10h 23minHard playthrough: 10h 43min (though it might as well be 20+ hours)So after I beat the game on normal I though I'd get my moneys worth and play the game on hard. It was deffenetly a challange if not fully frustrating at times and I got all but 1 achievement doing so as well as 100% of the items & upgrades.I did find a lot of flaws while doing so as well namely the game is locked to vsync and forcfully unlocking it is a bad idea. On windowed fullscreen it locks to 50hz on my system: I get it, PAL retro being assigned that. The visuals seem garnered for 720p so on a 1080p 24'' monitor the textures really suffer even with all the injected AA & AO.Soundtrack is fantastic, nothing wrong there.Some cinematics hide loading times, so expect some to be partially if not fully skip-able.You need a gamepad, though that's very much a given for 2D platformers.Then there are the bugs, like when I catapulted on a ledge in the research secot and teleported me all the way down (specifically the platforming challange part trying to get intel orbs). There are more, but I have to go back and catalogue them.An enjoyable game, but it has caveats.Also Meio's Tower can go die on the Hard difficulty, the last phase of the elevator is really annoying.Old Review: If you like Metroidvania this one does a lot right. Give it a go.If you like the Stider stuff this is very faithful and a loveletter to it.Could use some polish here and there, but nothing major.

												Reboot of Strider (1989): a 2D platform hack and slash game.Very decent game for those looking for this kind of game. While it does resemble the original game it was redone to fit today's standards.Pros: - Controls are very responsive specially with a gamepad - Upgrade system similar to metroid - Graphics are good - Music is decent - Levels are very well designed - Upgrades are well designed and useful - Fun and it doesn't get boringCons: - Voice actors speak like they're in a cartoon, most sound like morons and there's no Japanese option - Altough graphics are good, I'm not a fan of dark and exagerated bloom effect - 3D models lack detail and some look uninspired - Lacks variety in enemies and backgrounds - In the original Strider the enemies were anime styled, much cooler and colorful - In the original Strider the backgrounds were much more varied and colorful - The collectable items are not rewarding and kind of irrelevant - Short gameDespite the negative points I'm not complaining that the developers spent much more time in level design than graphics or created a short decent game rather than a long crappy game. content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Amazing, well planned and constructed maps; very visually appealing.  My only issue is with the play controls - I was expecting a loose control scheme, but was given a reactive-type instead.For example:When Strider gets close to a wall in midair, he reacts by grabbing onto the wall with his ninja tools.When Strider attacks an enemy with a shield, the game reacts by slowing the game for effect while his weapon bounces off the shield and stuns him.When Strider is struck in midair with practially anything, he reacts by falling to the ground and won't react until you've tried to jump several times.When Strider stands on a gravity globe, the controls react depending on which side of the globe you're on and you have to change which direction to hold on the control stick in order to keep moving.  This is especially frustrating during the final boss fight in which not only are you jumping from gravity globe to gravity globe but you're dodging seemingly random attacks that all stun on impact whether you're airborne or not.The game is great for what it is, but don't pick it up expecting a Metroidvania game - it's more a ninja-action game, which is really quite fitting the character and series.

												An average metroid-vania game with a hack-n-slash focus. While the combat is fun and frantic, it requires little finesse: Most rooms will be cleared with the same combination of abilities. content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												As far as I know, Strider was not a particularly commonly known franchise, which is a shame given how awesome the 2014 version is. This is speaking as someone who only has ever played the NES version, which despite being okay, wasn't the greatest game to hit the market. However, this one far exceeded any expectations I had.You are Strider Hiryu, your job is to kill Grandmaster Meio, but obviously no game could be as simple as THAT...and for good reason because Hiryu is a total badass and it's a pleasure to play longer just so you can kick serious heiney. It's a very action oriented game since you run, jump, and just generally hack anything that moves to death with Hiryu's Cypher, which apparently is some kind of tonfa-sword combo that can be powered with various plasma types. The game can probably best be described as a Metroidvania for those of you who know what that is. Hiryu must overcome various obstacles by searching out new weapons, abilities, and such to make it all around Meio's city.And that's where the game has me for sure. If you're the kind of person who loves adventuring all about, having to know what's around every corner, and getting a little excited when you find a new power-up that will let you be even MORE of a badass ninja than you already are, then yes, definitely a game to consider getting. I'm currently not finished with the game, but I've logged a number of hours already and the game say's I'm only about 60% of the way through.If there is one complaint to be had, I'll say that for normal difficulty, it seems particularly easy. Though I've done quite well at finding all the HP Upgrades, Hiryu doesn't take all too much damage unless you're standing around LETTING him get shot. If anything, the worst I've faced is when Hiryu falls into a trap and disappears and respawns on solid safe ground, which is more of an irritant than a real danger. Perhaps a harder difficulty on a later playthrough will give a bit more challenge, or possibly the game itself will bare its fangs when I get closer to the end.Overall, I'd say it's a solid game and I'm quite often finding it difficult to hit the Exit option when I really need to stop playing :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I beat Strider a couple of days ago, and it was awesome.Being a big fan of metroidvania genre, I wanted to play this game for a really long time. I've heard that people were having problems with repeated crashes, frame-rate drops and some confusing level design, but on my playthrough of Strider I didn't notice any of that stuff, well, maybe some FPS drops, but I can't call game a bad one just because of that.It was refreshing, yet familiar experience. I haven't played a whole lot of previous Strider games, but in this one I felt right at home. Graphics were stunning, ambient sounds and music that played occasionally were giving me right feel at the right time - there was some perfect sound both for action and for atmosphere. Controls were solid, if a little too complicated, but once I got used to them, everything became just right. Kazakh City was decently big and really fun to explore with rich variety of zones, though, some areas like Underground were a ♥♥♥♥♥ to get to. I was aiming to collect every collectible besides large green containers (they're nothing but a health refill item anyway) and this led to some frustration, because some of the little Strider icons, which give you costumes, were really challenging to collect. Other than those, I loved collecting all the items, but I missed a few optional icons with concept art, which isn't a big deal.The core gameplay of Strider was fun and addictive, I spent hours just running around, killing bad guys in style and jumping on the rooftops like madman. Bosses were memorable and very challenging, except for Gravitrons (I was seriously just sitting in one spot and throwing exploding kunai at them until they broke). Final stage was epic and fight with Grandmaster Meio felt like complete joke after such a hard stage. Still, I enjoyed it and the victory was pretty sweet.The game was constantly throwing new stuff, enemies and objectives at me, helping to learn new tactics and kept me entertained until the very end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20
												Pretty solid modernized version of Strider with Metroid-like level progression, though I wouldn't consider it a fully fledged metroidvania game since exploration aspect in this game is pretty pale. Takes around 7 hours to 100%. Navigation outside of main objectives isn't very fun and there aren't any real points of interest besides color-coded locked doors which usually hide a power-up or concept art unlock.Game itself is more combat oriented and that's where is shines. All animations are fast and don't cancel anything (e.g. you can jump, throw kunai and power up your slash at the same time), plus you get 4 different attack types that change how your combat moves behave, neither mode is a direct upgrade but instead they compliment each other (e.g. use reflective mode to reflect bullets while you run torwards the enemy, switch to magnetic mode and dash to stun them, and then switch to flame mode to finish the stunned enemy off). Most locked doors are opened by a dash so you don't have to pause while moving from area to area either. There are no pauses during movement or combat, it feels very streamlined and fast-paced.Visuals are nice and clean, have a nice style (e.g. some effects like dust or explosions look more hand-drawn than realistic), but nothing to write home about. Enemies telegraph their shots and projectiles are very easy to see. Bosses make great use of projectiles, something you would see in old arcade games. Bosses in this game are in general very fun and challenging, and urge you to move a lot, unlike some other modern metroidvania games (*cough*Shadow Complex*cough*).One thing that puzzles me is complete lack of facial animations during cutscenes. It's not noticable on Hiryu and some other characters that wear masks, but it looks very cheap on characters that don't.Some issues with the game: Game is locked at 60 fps. You can't remap keys in-game, but you can do so by editing config files. Non-XInput controllers are supported only through third-party means (x360ce). Controls during segments that have non-standard gravity are just plain bad both on keyboard and controller, but these segments are rare and it doesn't ruin them completely.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I'll never forget the first time I saw Strider in the Arcade, I was blown away (The visuals! The sounds!! The bosses!!!) It was like a magnet for my Alladdin's Castle Tokens...Fast forward to the announcement of an NES version of the game...I was super psyched (hmm...these screenshots aren't quite what I'm expecting...). Now fast forward again to the release of the NES game (What is this...it's nothing like the Arcade?!), then suddenly (Wait a minute, this is pretty cool...), and finally (This is one of the greatest NES games ever!!!)Several years later I became the unfortunate owner of the Turd known as "Strider 2" by US GOLD for the Amiga. I couldn't resist when I saw the box at the store (Strider 2, are you kidding me!). The excitement only lasted a few short seconds...(Looks kind of like Strider, Sounds kind of like Strider...wait...did I just morph into a robot with tank treads for feet?!?! What the hell is this garbage!). It was so bad I had repressed the memory, only to have it crawl from the stinky depths while writing this review. US GOLD were The Masters of Dissapointment...Sh@tting all over some of my favorite franchises.Strider 2 on PS1 (alright, now we're back in business!) was pretty solid, and although didn't quite have that magic that I had found in the original Arcade or NES game, it was another good Strider game (nothing wrong with that!).Over the last 14 years, Hiryu would occasionally appear in Capcom games as an extra or playable charachter and this gave me some hope that they hadn't forgotten about one of my favorites.There was also Moon Diver on XBLA that was very "Stider-esque" and I believe was made by some former capcom employees, and that was decent...Then came the announcement of this game...Initially I was excited, but apprehensive (what if it's not good...) so for some reason I held off. After hearing a friend mention how much he liked the new game, I decided it was time to give it a shot. In short, I love this game! It's like a delicious combo platter of the Original 2 (arcade & NES) Strider games, with chunky bits of strider 2 mixed in, all served up on a tasty Metroidvania platter. The graphics are great, the Sound is great, the controls are great (xb360 controller), there's lots to see and do, plenty of abilities and secrets to find, and there are some epic boss battles.  What more could I ask for? Not much...If you like a good MetroidVania game, you'll like this. If you like a good Metroidvania game, and you like Strider, chances are you'll love this as much as I do.

Posted: February 13, 2016
Highly recommended if you can play it with a controller. Otherwise...A solid, fast-paced action game with a Metroid-like exploration and high frame rate even on a 3-years-old laptop :D I've bought it on sale, but it would have been worth every single cent at full price XDOnly two real CONs:* on older computers (or older graphic cards) the game could perform really badly, since there is no frame skip. As a result, everything will go in slow-motion, killing the purpose of the game itself :/* to play it with some USB controllers, it is necessary to download a third-party tool/key mapper (e.g. X360CE) - as for many other games around here :/Oh, and trust me: a controller is indeed needed. Attempting to play this game with a keyboard will lead to frequent rage quits or key smashing. Without a controller, it's extremely difficult to play properly, given the dynamic feeling and pace of the game itself.Highly recommended! Every real fan of Metroidvania games and classic arcade scrolling games should give it a try!

												Must be about 23 years since I first played Strider on my old Sega. When I saw this on the Steam store I had to check it out. Remake with modern graphics and gameplay... I've seen these before and they never really turn out to be good. Since this was on offer I decided to give it a chance, and wow...I must say I'm very impressed. If you played the old school or not, this game is definitely worth a try. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I did not know what to expect coming into Strider.  I only had a passing awareness of what the game was from AGDQ and Hiryu's likeness from other games.  So, no expectations.I have to say, though, that Strider is really good at what it is.  I went straight to the hardest difficulty and didn't have much trouble except for a few bosses, so it's not a difficult game, but it is a good game.  The level design is definitely that classic Metroidvania-style and the sheer number of collectables and power-ups provides plenty of reason to backtrack to get it all.There's not much enemy diversity and most of them can be felled by actually just mashing the attack button, but the game still rewards planning and awareness, especially through a few key sections that are basically bullet hells.  Some of the segments are basically puzzle-platformers, others are straight-on combat, and the variance is nice.  The game is paced well.My one major gripe with the game is a gravity mechanic that comes into play a few times (including the final boss fight).  The controls while in gravity fields are not intuitive, so I had to fight my instincts in order to get fluid movement.  This mechanic is only used three times in the entire game, so it's not game-wrecking, just an occasional annoyance.A good game.  I intend to 100% it soon.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Very fun concept and constant gameplay changes are what you can expect from this recreation of Capcom's classic side scrolling action adventure. Enemy variety, multiple weapon effects and upgrades go very good in combination with this very fast game. Controls are great and super responsive (I played on the controller), offer excellent character and situational control and for this reason its way too easy since enemies are pretty dumb and extremely easy to defeat, no exception! This game is super forgiving, even on the hardest difficulty setting where everything except for one or maybe two boss battles was just a mindless button mashing with barely any strategy involved which resulted in total annihilation of every enemy and numbness in my thumb. Its still pretty damn fun but feels to me like a wasted potential for a very good, tactical, hardcore action game. Maybe not the the most memorable game you will play but certainly a fun one.Pros:- Fun, fast & fluid gameplay- Smooth and responsive- New move every now and then- Beautiful graphics- Freedom of movementCons:- Very easy and shallow despite amazing character controll and multiple weapons- Story is so unimportant that I don't even remember it now, couple of hours after i finished the game- Would be much better if it had a good OST

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												A brilliant metroidvania with everything you could possibly want from the genre, themed around a cyber-ninja. The controls are tight, the level design is supurb (as is the location of the hidden goodies) and the graphics are really nice. The music is good, the array of weapons is varied and feels constantly progressive with each new item, just as the wide array of enemies steadily becomes more tricky to deal with. This game is hard, make no mistake, but they give you all the tools you need to survive, so the rest is up to learning patterns and being smart.I only have two issues: Firstly, the occasional ambient dialogue has a huge subtitle box, which can sometimes obscure what's going on (in one encounter, I couldn't seen my character at all when he wasn't jumping). Secondly, there's no facial animation - a small annoyance, and perhaps understandable when 90% of the characters have their face covered, or are too small to see outside of cutscenes... but it is something that bugs me, in any game.Highly recommended to any fans of the genre or ninja themes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Rating: 7/10 - A fun platform game, with light Metroidvania elements. Completion time: 7:30.= THE GOOD =- It's a very fun game to play; you slay eniemies, upon enemies, upon enemies- Very stylish graphics- Very responsive controls- The weapons, and their upgrades, are quite interesting, and make sense (although at the end, you'll use only plasma type 3 and 4)- The enemies are relatively varied- The bosses are quite fun- The maps are relatively large= THE SO-SO =- Although the graphics are beautiful, it lacks the variety and creativity of the first Strider, which is a big big shame- This could be somewhat classified as Metroidvania, although it's quite linear - in reality, you're only going to do a big backtrack at the end to pick up the missing powerups- The NPE/Bosses don't move their mouths while talking; this makes them a bit weird looking.= THE BAD =- You can't customize the keys. Arcade stick is not supported- You need 11 keys (ELEVEN!!) plus the 4 directions when playing, plus another 6/7 other ones used exclusively in map mode. This is very irritating; they could have made a more economic and intelligent choice.- Shielded enemies of type 2 can only be killed with Plasma 2, not 3/4. This has no real strategic implications; it will only force the player to switch the plasma, klll the enemy, and switch back again, which is nothing else than annoying- Many bosses will need to be killed several times over the game. It's quite boring to meet a past boss again.- You can't skip the bosses' blabbering, which is cheesy and banal, and ultimately irritating- The controls in "floating" gravity are a terrible mess, especially in the last boss- There is no ending. DAFUQ!?!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												While I did enjoy this game, it comes with a few things that to me felt like grievous issues.Cons:Camera - The camera is almsot always fine, but in a few boss fights it zooms in and out at horrible times and pulls away from the boss to follow Strider.  It's even worse around gravity globes you can run on, which are their own irritating issue that just becomes more annoying.No invincibility frames - A few normal enemies and a few boss attacks have their entire gimmick around this and squeezing as much damage as possible in one volley or chain stuns.  Easily a quarter or more of a fully upgraded health from one of those, or just getting pinballed between 2-4 enemies for a few seconds while you wait for the chance to have control again.Other smaller issues involve the final tower level being a boring difficulty spike and that wall climbing has you suddenly mantle up and over from a bit too generous of a distance.  Also there's an entire level where you run against the wind meaning you walk slow and jump short distances; meh.The Good:Movement is amazing.  Running, dashing, jumping, and sliding around while slashing everything in sight is solid and the best part of the game.  Worth a playthrough alone just to hop around and hit stuff really.The Metroidvaia aspect feels tacked on with four flavors (ice, fire, reflect, magnetic/ranged) to the dash, slash, and kunais, but overall is fun while you do a little backtracking here and there and have a dramatic pose animation that plays each time you pick up an upgrade.  Also ignore the story.  Not because the story is really bad, but because it's just in the way of the fun and makes deaths to bosses involve watching another boring taunt speech.For all of the negatives, I do still recommend this game oddly.  It's that much fun to play when the quirks aren't getting in your face.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I did not know what to expect coming into Strider.  I only had a passing awareness of what the game was from AGDQ and Hiryu's likeness from other games.  So, no expectations.I have to say, though, that Strider is really good at what it is.  I went straight to the hardest difficulty and didn't have much trouble except for a few bosses, so it's not a difficult game, but it is a good game.  The level design is definitely that classic Metroidvania-style and the sheer number of collectables and power-ups provides plenty of reason to backtrack to get it all.There's not much enemy diversity and most of them can be felled by actually just mashing the attack button, but the game still rewards planning and awareness, especially through a few key sections that are basically bullet hells.  Some of the segments are basically puzzle-platformers, others are straight-on combat, and the variance is nice.  The game is paced well.My one major gripe with the game is a gravity mechanic that comes into play a few times (including the final boss fight).  The controls while in gravity fields are not intuitive, so I had to fight my instincts in order to get fluid movement.  This mechanic is only used three times in the entire game, so it's not game-wrecking, just an occasional annoyance.A good game.  I intend to 100% it soon.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Strider is a great 2D action side scroller.  It's fast paced, requires a fair bit of finger dexterity, and is roughly a 12-hour game if you take your time to complete ~85% of the game on Normal.  The graphics and sound a fantastic as well.I can't remember any crashes or hangs, so it's quite stable as well.Like other 2D side scrollers of this sort, you get what you put in.  If you run through the game and skip most bad guys, and skipping out on the exploring and grabbing upgrades then it would grow old fast.  However, if you do generally the opposite then the game offers quite a bit of challenge and diversity to keep you interested.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												Overall a very fun, albeit short, Metroidvania title.  What it lacks in story it makes up for in the fluid, fast-paced combat and wonderful visuals as well as controls that feel really good (at least with a controller).   Game can be completed within probably 4-8 hours depending on whether or not you try to find all the hidden upgrades and collectibles (costumes (which are just recolors), enemy intel, concept art, etc.).   Doesn't really have much for replayability and navigating back to previous areas to collect stuff can feel daunting, but overall it's a fun little game for the length it provides. Would recommend waiting for it to be on sale as you probably won't get 15 hours out of it unless you're a completionist or enjoy the gameplay enough to play it a few times through.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Pretty fun, but some nitpicks.1. Kind of short (I got almost everything in the game in about 8-9 hours)2. Inconsistent difficulty (Starts off balanced, gets fairly difficult, then becomes extremely easy, save a couple of boss fights and some incredibly annoying combinations of enemies, plus Meio is a pain to fight given how his arena is built)3. Weapons are rather unbalanced (Reflect (red) plasma is entirely outclassed by the other three, I just left explosive/fire on unless I needed to cheese something with homing kunai or slowly chip my way through a line of stunlock laser soldiers with the ice sword since explosive does the most damage)4. Movement can be really finicky and annoying in some situations (The plasma catapult has a weird hop on the end of its animation that can get you killed, Strider will stick to any wall he gets too close to so you can get killed trying to hop down a small gap such as in the Meio fight, some knockdown and stagger animations don't end unless you hit the ground requiring you to climb back up a huge room due to one enemy, those freeze-canister spider droids can easily stunlock you to death with spammed attacks since there's no stunlock protection, etc)Otherwise, it's a really solid, fun game with some challenging platforming, fun boss fights, and great combat. Plus, it's pretty cheap.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Repetitive action gameplay with clean controls and an infuriating knockback mechanic. As a strider game, it is OK. (Recommend)As a metroidvania game, it is quite disappointing. (Do NOT recommend)PROS:-Clean controls-Good boss fights-Variety of collectiblesNEUTRALS:-Different weapon types don't really do anything different (except the freeze)-No real combat mechanics. The entire game you just mash  to swing your sword, and once you have kunais you also mash to throw those at the same time. Over and over. -Maybe 3 or 4 "actual" enemy types? (Wall cannons, soldiers w/ and w/o shields, and the 6 legged bot guys)CONS:-INCREDIBLY ANNOYING KNOCKBACK MECHANIC withOUT invul frames.....expect to get annoyed being knocked down cliffs, etc, and towards the end of the game you will get mini-chain stunned on the harder difficulty. -Metroidvania elements are barely implemented. Yes there are levels with collectibles strewn about, but the only thing preventing you from accessing them is colored doors (which can be opened by the various weapon types). There are very few hidden items (for example, one requires you to freeze a number of enemies and use them as stepping stones to cross a large gap....this type of hidden item is extremely rare in the game). Usually you just get the weapon, open the matching door, and upgrades voila.-No fast travel mechanic (although the game says the panther is supposed to be, it isn't and there are only like 2 points where its active anyway)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I beat Strider a couple of days ago, and it was awesome.Being a big fan of metroidvania genre, I wanted to play this game for a really long time. I've heard that people were having problems with repeated crashes, frame-rate drops and some confusing level design, but on my playthrough of Strider I didn't notice any of that stuff, well, maybe some FPS drops, but I can't call game a bad one just because of that.It was refreshing, yet familiar experience. I haven't played a whole lot of previous Strider games, but in this one I felt right at home. Graphics were stunning, ambient sounds and music that played occasionally were giving me right feel at the right time - there was some perfect sound both for action and for atmosphere. Controls were solid, if a little too complicated, but once I got used to them, everything became just right. Kazakh City was decently big and really fun to explore with rich variety of zones, though, some areas like Underground were a ♥♥♥♥♥ to get to. I was aiming to collect every collectible besides large green containers (they're nothing but a health refill item anyway) and this led to some frustration, because some of the little Strider icons, which give you costumes, were really challenging to collect. Other than those, I loved collecting all the items, but I missed a few optional icons with concept art, which isn't a big deal.The core gameplay of Strider was fun and addictive, I spent hours just running around, killing bad guys in style and jumping on the rooftops like madman. Bosses were memorable and very challenging, except for Gravitrons (I was seriously just sitting in one spot and throwing exploding kunai at them until they broke). Final stage was epic and fight with Grandmaster Meio felt like complete joke after such a hard stage. Still, I enjoyed it and the victory was pretty sweet.The game was constantly throwing new stuff, enemies and objectives at me, helping to learn new tactics and kept me entertained until the very end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
IntroI love platformers like the Megaman series and ninja games where every move counts, challenging and rewarding at the same time. I love finding secrets and unlocking new moves, that's precisely why I wanted this game. Strider was fun to some extent especially the boss fights and the platforming system. You can climb on walls and even on ceilings. There is a reward system of course which presents you with new upgrades that adds you your weapon collection adding to the fun. However, the game lacks in many aspects and I will try to cover these in this review of the game. Shallow Fighting SystemThe whole game system encourages the player to rush through the enemies and end them as fast as possible which is expected of a ninja and should be good if implemented right, but the problem here is that enemies come in large quantities and spam you with bullets that stumbles the player. You may be able to play the game slowly and kill enemies without losing health but it will take forever, plus regular enemies are tough to beat and I don't mean tough to fight, the game makes them harder to crack when hit. Throughout the game, the only effective moves you'll be using is your normal sword strike or the charge strike. RepetitiveThe game is extremely repetitive, it reuses a lot of enemies and (you guessed it) it also uses the same bosses all to extend the length of the game. I have been playing this game for five hours and I'm still fighting the same soldiers that I met at the first level. I'm not even sure, they might have changed the color of their eyes but I'm pretty sure that they are the same except, now they are more in quantity and with various weapons to use. Adding cruelty to injury, sometimes they even use a shield to prevent you from passing which is really annoying to deal with. They also spawn back when you reenter the room.The Problem With Level DesignThe level design, the levels are well done and the platforming is fun. The placement of enemies is also clever and hard to pass without thinking of how to approach them. There are doors which require special keys to open and pass through and there are also secrets with rewards. But the problem is the foreground and the background are sometimes confusing. Especially when you play this game for the first time, you'll have trouble finding doors and vents without looking at your minimap. I find myself, most of the time, constantly looking at the minimap to make sure I didn't miss anything. Also, there is lack of variety in designing the levels. In a normal platformer, you expect a climate change, a day time a night time. These things are important to me and I think they keep things fresh for the player. The game changes environments but not much, it is all about fighting in a modern city, a factory or underground which all look like the same place to me.Many Worthless RewardsThe reward System, every now and then, the game rewards the player with new powers to use. My problem with this is that most of these rewards are mere keys to new areas. Most of them are useless in a fight and you'll be more inclined to use your sword in fights instead of wasting your energy on those moves. An example of a useless reward is the kuni, a ninja projectile used to throw at enemies and instantly kill them (supposedly). But instead, if you use it on enemies in this game it's like throwing stones at an armored soldier. Plus, it only can be thrown halfway through the screen and then disappears. The only useful thing about this item is that some locks are only activated by using it.ConclusionAt the end, Strider is a fun game and a good platformer. It offers great boss fights and will keep you active throughout the game. The game however is repetitive and sometimes doesn't reward the player properly. You might be playing this game for a while but be prepared to spam the same button over and over to defeat all your enemies. If I have to give it a score I would give it 5/10. I hope those issues are addressed in their next game, otherwise, I'm not buying it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Admittedly, it's really difficult to get me to get into a side-scrolling game. It's just something I've experienced so much, from puzzle games to fighting games to action games... Eventually, it starts to get stale. That's what I find so incredibly refreshing about this game. My impression shifted from 'this is way too simple' to 'this is crazy awesome' really, really fast.In terms of story and setting, I knew hardly anything about Strider, but this game throws you right into the fray in a heartbeat. There was so much to appreciate about this game at first. The art direction is gorgeous, for one, and the gameplay is bizarrely smooth. Each button tap of your weapon is a sword attack. Every single one. If you spam the 'X' button, you attack that many times --it's really one to one. Jumping felt a little wonky at first, but I quickly adapted to it, and once I did, I was warped into a crazy fluid combat experience.Admittedly, I was worried that 'jumping and sword slashing' would be all to the combat, but the game quickly provided me with a series of upgrades and attacks that really refreshed my palette. By mid-game, the combat was borderline addicting, and I could hardly put my controller down. Jumping back and forth, dodging attacks, reflecting bullets, switching elemental strengths and plunging in for a strike --it was all incredibly satisfying. To its detriment, though, this game is -really- difficult, particularly in some segments. I mean, I usually play games on hard rather than normal, because I think developers sometimes dumb games down for the masses, but even normal was a big challenge (Particularly a certain elevator that had me rage quit a few times.) Also, checkpoints. Don't think that just because you respawned before a boss fight means that if you turn off your game, your progress is saved. A couple of times, I had to restart half a level because I quit the game before another checkpoint without even realizing.That aside, though? It's a pretty good deal for a game that swept me away otherwise. You'll get maybe 6 hours if you blow through it, and 10 if you go secret-hunting. Get it for under $10, you'll not regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Strider is a 1990s-style Metroidvania made with the technology and game design sensibilities of the 21st century. A solid and attractive platformer built around a rather nonsensical plot, the game runs the player through a variety of environments as they slowly unlock new abilities for the main character, allowing them to access more and more of the world in a fairly linear fashion.This game takes the design of Metroidvania games and does it much better. Backtracking? There isn’t much of it here; the game is designed to take the player on a linear route through the world, and while it feels nice and convoluted, the overall amount of backtracking is very minimal. This is an excellent piece of game design that many other Metroidvanias could learn from; the only real backtracking required is a few areas which have to be unlocked by later abilities.The core gameplay itself is pretty enjoyable. The platforming feels good, you can climb along the walls and ceilings, there aren’t too many bottomless pits, the enemies are reasonably varied, there are tons and tons of bosses (about one every half hour or so), with new enemies introduced like clockwork in the meanwhile. The game is always kept feeling fresh, and at the end, you get to put all your skills to work taking down the big bad.The game has decent voice acting, but the plot itself is pretty much nonsense; it isn’t really clear what is going on beyond “There is a bad guy who is in charge and you need to kill him.” Who sent Strider? Who are all these people? Why is the big bad doing what he is doing? Who knows? Who cares? It doesn’t matter!Your goal is to cut your way through his minions, and the game employs you admirably in this.Overall, this is a pretty great game. The graphics ae solid, the game is the right length for what it is and doesn’t feel stretched at about 9 hours to 100% it, the protagonist has a reasonably diverse set of skills which can be employed in a few different ways to make your way through the levels and beat down the bad guys – if I had a complaint, it would be that the standard game difficulty might have been a touch on the easy side at times, but overall, it wasn’t really an issue. Checkpoints were pretty generous and never really felt like they set you back too far even if you did fail.Was it perfect? No. But I had fun playing it, and the game had excellent pacing which kept me interested and kept me wanting to play after I got rolling through to the very end, even though it gave me many, many possible break points to choose from.All in all, this is a great reboot, and the game was really quite fun and was worth the 9 hours I invested. It isn’t something with a great story, but the core gameplay was pretty much exactly what I was hoping for from a game like this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Strider is a great game that any platformer, action-packed loving gamer should have in their collection. If you want to know much about this game, here are the points I have written in details, and I have avoided spoilers.:1/ Story: The game story is nice, albeit a little bit too simple, but sufficient enough.2/ Platforming: The puzzles, obstacles in the game are well-designed. You will need to acquire the skills in the game to get past a lot of obstacles. The Devs really have thoroughly put their thoughts and mind into designing these obstacles. 3/ Exploration: As you play in a huge city, Strider is full of places to visit if you decide not to stick to the guide and instruction from the game. Try wandering around the city on your own, you will discover a huge lot of fun things to do.However, bear in mind that this is merely a little open-world type of game. There won't be side-quests. And sometimes if you happen to be in somewhere you haven't been before, or re-visited randomly, there may be boss battles, so prepare yourself well. But don't worry, the game won't put you into a random boss battle if it doesn't know you have the skills required to enter that battle.But after you get some skills, you could go around and try visiting the old places to get more power-ups. If you are afraid that you might get lost, use the Maps.4/ Maps: However, sometimes, you will need to do some zoom-in and out for the Maps. I did had a problem with the Map when trying to switch from one area to another, since the Map of another area might disappear from the screen, and you could not see anything. In this case, I would recommend trying move the arrow keys around, try zoom-in and zoom-out, you will get over this problem easily.5/ Power-ups, upgrades: Strider offers a good variety of power-ups you will need to win the combat. From Ice, Flame, to Magnetic, Kunai, Option A-B-C (you will figure it out what they are) or skills such as Projectile Reflecting with your sword... and much more, it's definitely great to play such as a game with so many things you can use to deal with the enemies. These upgrades will also help you in exploring the city. And using them to get to strange places you have never been to before.6/ Combat + Boss: Definitely the best points to talk about. If there's anything I would recommend, it would be going for the Hard mode when you start playing the game.Trust me, it's gonna be one huge fun to do. That's what I did when I first played this game. Going for the Hard mode in Strider not only makes you realize how much important it is to explore the city to get more power-ups, costumes (did I mention there are 11 awesome costumes in this game?), concept art.. but also to make you prepare yourself harshly for go into the battle with the Bosses.For 1 or 2 first bosses of the game, you will feel like the game is pretty harsh on your Health, since the Bosses at Hard mode are no joke, they mean serious business if you don't master your dodging and sword slicing skill well enough. But after getting your hands on some Energy and Health upgrades, you will realize the Boss battles are much gonna be easier. They will only have one or two fatal strikes at you. So try Hard mode, it's totally encouraging. Even the damage of normal minions, enemies are gonna be a lot strong, so try to get a lot of upgrades. By the time you reach the Final Boss, believe me, the Final Boss would not be hard to finish.As for the Combat: I would state it in two words "Button Mashing". I can spoil you on this one, but it means, in the boss battle, if you want to win (Well, I'm still talking about Hard mode) without letting yourself getting killed fast by the Bosses' damage, you would do well to hit those guys as fast as you could. Since the number of consecutive hits on them do matters in this game, hit them fast will help you increase your own damage. Therefore, you will have pressed a button, like , 200-300 times after this game, and that's ok :DWell, that's about everything I can tell you. I totally would play this game all over again. Because Strider is a great game. And it's gonna be totally worthy of your own money.Score: 9.5/10. -0.5 because of the Maps >.>

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												Holy crap, I can't believe I debated on whether to buy this game.  Got it on the Daily Deal for 4 and a half bucks, then proceeded to play for 3 and a half hours straight.  Great fun.This game reminds me of when I was a kid, and playing those great Nintendo and Sega platformers that you couldn't wait to get home from school to play.  Not so much because it's Strider, but because it doesn't try to be "Next-Gen", and just focuses on great gameplay.  There's no weird sh*t or gimmicks to pull your attention away.It's also not a heavy lift - controls are precise and simple.  This is a game with a lot of hidden stuff, but it also WANTS you to find that hidden stuff.  There's some backtracking involved to get to hidden items (like when you gain a new ability, and so can reach/break a previously unreachable/unbreakable doorway), but it never comes off as tedious.Well worth the cost, even at full price.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Pretty fun, but some nitpicks.1. Kind of short (I got almost everything in the game in about 8-9 hours)2. Inconsistent difficulty (Starts off balanced, gets fairly difficult, then becomes extremely easy, save a couple of boss fights and some incredibly annoying combinations of enemies, plus Meio is a pain to fight given how his arena is built)3. Weapons are rather unbalanced (Reflect (red) plasma is entirely outclassed by the other three, I just left explosive/fire on unless I needed to cheese something with homing kunai or slowly chip my way through a line of stunlock laser soldiers with the ice sword since explosive does the most damage)4. Movement can be really finicky and annoying in some situations (The plasma catapult has a weird hop on the end of its animation that can get you killed, Strider will stick to any wall he gets too close to so you can get killed trying to hop down a small gap such as in the Meio fight, some knockdown and stagger animations don't end unless you hit the ground requiring you to climb back up a huge room due to one enemy, those freeze-canister spider droids can easily stunlock you to death with spammed attacks since there's no stunlock protection, etc)Otherwise, it's a really solid, fun game with some challenging platforming, fun boss fights, and great combat. Plus, it's pretty cheap.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Repetitive action gameplay with clean controls and an infuriating knockback mechanic. As a strider game, it is OK. (Recommend)As a metroidvania game, it is quite disappointing. (Do NOT recommend)PROS:-Clean controls-Good boss fights-Variety of collectiblesNEUTRALS:-Different weapon types don't really do anything different (except the freeze)-No real combat mechanics. The entire game you just mash  to swing your sword, and once you have kunais you also mash to throw those at the same time. Over and over. -Maybe 3 or 4 "actual" enemy types? (Wall cannons, soldiers w/ and w/o shields, and the 6 legged bot guys)CONS:-INCREDIBLY ANNOYING KNOCKBACK MECHANIC withOUT invul frames.....expect to get annoyed being knocked down cliffs, etc, and towards the end of the game you will get mini-chain stunned on the harder difficulty. -Metroidvania elements are barely implemented. Yes there are levels with collectibles strewn about, but the only thing preventing you from accessing them is colored doors (which can be opened by the various weapon types). There are very few hidden items (for example, one requires you to freeze a number of enemies and use them as stepping stones to cross a large gap....this type of hidden item is extremely rare in the game). Usually you just get the weapon, open the matching door, and upgrades voila.-No fast travel mechanic (although the game says the panther is supposed to be, it isn't and there are only like 2 points where its active anyway)

												I'm not a big fan of classic Strider but I really dug this game. It's a neat marriage of the fast-paced slashy gameplay of the original and a Metroid-esque structure. Really good game with great, fluid and fun controls. The only real complaint I have is that the bosses kind of suck. If you try to learn their patterns they'll often blow you away with powerful attacks, but if you just go right up to them and mash buttons you'll almost always win. It's also sort of easy but not insultingly so. Those points aside it's highly recommended, it's a quick, frenetic and thoughtful platformer that doesn't wear out its welcome.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												While I did enjoy this game, it comes with a few things that to me felt like grievous issues.Cons:Camera - The camera is almsot always fine, but in a few boss fights it zooms in and out at horrible times and pulls away from the boss to follow Strider.  It's even worse around gravity globes you can run on, which are their own irritating issue that just becomes more annoying.No invincibility frames - A few normal enemies and a few boss attacks have their entire gimmick around this and squeezing as much damage as possible in one volley or chain stuns.  Easily a quarter or more of a fully upgraded health from one of those, or just getting pinballed between 2-4 enemies for a few seconds while you wait for the chance to have control again.Other smaller issues involve the final tower level being a boring difficulty spike and that wall climbing has you suddenly mantle up and over from a bit too generous of a distance.  Also there's an entire level where you run against the wind meaning you walk slow and jump short distances; meh.The Good:Movement is amazing.  Running, dashing, jumping, and sliding around while slashing everything in sight is solid and the best part of the game.  Worth a playthrough alone just to hop around and hit stuff really.The Metroidvaia aspect feels tacked on with four flavors (ice, fire, reflect, magnetic/ranged) to the dash, slash, and kunais, but overall is fun while you do a little backtracking here and there and have a dramatic pose animation that plays each time you pick up an upgrade.  Also ignore the story.  Not because the story is really bad, but because it's just in the way of the fun and makes deaths to bosses involve watching another boring taunt speech.For all of the negatives, I do still recommend this game oddly.  It's that much fun to play when the quirks aren't getting in your face.

content:
Posted: January 1
												One thing I've learned about video games over the years is that the story doesn't matter in the slightest in the face of gameplay, and few big-name games these days carry that sentiment.Strider is one such game.The game starts, and you immediately get thrown into the action with zero exposition; this immediately highlights Striders core gameplay: the combat. The combat is fun, fast, fluid, f-intuitive, and it blends very well with movement around the area, as Hiryu can attack in virtually all directions, even in movement.Admittedly, I finished the game and I still don't fully understand what was what in the overall plot, but I don't care because the gameplay is fun enough that I would play it a second time.

Posted: January 10
												Great game, lives up to the high standard set by the original game but ofc with far better graphics and music.It starts off a little rough and you'll most likely die a lot (this is a game you might want to consider playing on easy if you want to finish it as a normie), but as you progress you get upgrades and with these the game becomes a lot more enjoyable to play.  You also get a lot of game for your money, took me around 20 hours to finish off the last boss and I had 49% map completion.  Lots of other collectables, different game modes like survival etc.Fun game for a cheap price, a must have for fans of the original Strider or sidescroller type games in general.

content:
Posted: April 7
												I got this game expecting to be the very arcade style with short levels full of action. While that's not what I got, the metroidvania style fits well with Strider's mechanics. Despite the big maps you can travel quick and kill enemies quicker. The game also rewards skilled players with a special metter making you stronger for a short time, so is not just rushing through.There's really no much else to point out. The story is super simple with plain cutscenes but the series wasn't known for its plot. And like many of its genre there's a good bunch of upgrades and collectables to look for. Overall a very solid game that won't disappoint both newcomers and veterans of the series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 8
												Strider by Double Helix is a great side scrolling adventure, the game features crisp controls a variety of abilites, power-ups, tough yet reachable achievements and a few good play throughs. The design and methods our crafty Ninja Hero Hiryu goes about climbing, flipping, slicing, dicing, teleporting, and projecting himself through the multiple levels of this game is a blast, the action, the pace, the difficulty at not getting hit, loading up your cypher sword and going all out on some unfortunate Meio kronies is a thrilling ride...for awhile.One of the achievements and probably the most worrisome is the complete in 4 hours achievement - this is totally possible on any setting as the games areas to travel and places to go are limited, with the help of a few maps from online you can plot a course that will take you directly or almost near direct paths with almost all power ups to beat the game in 4 hours. I completed it in 3:05 and think I missed 1 power up.Strider had very few cons, I think 3 overall:The first and biggest one is that Double Helix the designer of the game is no longer in business. Strider has such a comfortable blend of action, evasion, and puzzles while it glides along quickly enough that you can beat it in under 4 hours once youve honed your skill. The Second con would be that is it such a short game, there are some extra modes like survival where you try to survive wave after wave of enemies or the time trials where you run around the maps hitting beacons in a certain time frame to collect A - F rank, but they got old quick. The Third is the Direct X, if you dont have DX11 it cant run on your machine, some people have posted about this, and there is supposedly patches (unofficial patches)- youve been warned.If your a platform player this is a must, wait for a sale and enjoy. If you dont usually play platform style games and seek a top of line experience in this genre with top notch quality and representation - Strider is a excellent choice.

content:
Posted: February 6
												Well-built Metroidvania game with as much focus on plot as I imagine the original NES game had (none). Feels ultra responsive and withstanding a couple of exceptions plays very well. When you're on a wall, you can't melee below you. Really seems like they just didn't have time to implement it. Gameplay is definitely the strongest part and as you pick up skills it becomes varied and challenging. Exploration is rewarded and the levels are very well designed. Complex but I never felt stuck nor accidentally backtracked though you are generally able to.Looks pretty nice. Voice acting and remnants of plot are mostly atrocious. Would almost be better if it was just silent. Music could have been cooler too. I guess like.. the game didn't really have much character and felt super generic and the bosses and well everything had no context. The game is good, but I feel it will be fairly forgettable.

content:
Posted: February 14
												STRIDER's visuals and theme are not my style. It tends to feel a bit button-mashy as times, as well, which really turns me off. On top of that, you acquire a weapon about 1/3 of the way through the game that you simply spam to beat nearly every boss afterwards. The exploration is also a bit tedious. All that said, STRIDER provides you with a lot of fun weapons to play with, has a straightforward progression system, and plays faster than any Metroidvania title I've experienced to date. It's a solid offering if you're looking for something different.

content:
Posted: February 26
Strider is a good action game, but a lame Metroidvania. Strider is a reboot of... well, the Strider franchise. Strider was a dose of intense arcadey goodness, and when I heard it was rebooted as a Metroidvania, I was pretty surprised, but ready to give it a chance.On the side of action, the game succeeds. Unfortunately, there's not a lot I can say that speaks to this. It feels as flashy and wild as it should. Bosses are frantic, enemies are dynamic, and the abilities you acquire are fun and empowering, kunais, dashes, new blade types, etc. My only real complaints here are that at the occasional gravity warping sections within the game, you never feel quite as in control as you should, and that switiching blade types on the fly can feel stressful. Oh, and turning around is kind of weird? But anyway. Graphically, it's exactly what it should be, throwbacks to the old games show up in proper spaces, but also aren't carbon copies. The soundtrack is actually really sick, unfortunately it is turned down too low to appreciate, like a lot of soundtracks nowadays. I recommend cranking it up a little! But otherwise, the combat is nice, the presentation works. Playtime is around five hours, and that's just about the right length. It all checks out.But then we get to the fact that, again, this game is a Metroidvania. That means backtracking to get collectibles with new found power ups. But the issue with Strider's layout is that backtracking is genuinely annoying to go through. There are only a few warp points in the game, and they are far out of the way from the "Plaza" (the place you consistently return to over the game). The collectibles, too, are almost never worth going to get, with the exception of a few upgrades to your health and mechanical upgrades. Furthermore, rather than in a, well, GOOD Metroidvania, you aren't led silently to where you need to go to next by map design and the designer's invisible hand. You're given a waypoint on the map to head to. What was the point of making this a Metroidvania, then? If the areas were stacked in order, the game would have felt relatively the same, though a bit funky to backtrack through small parts of areas. I often feel compelled to collect everything I can in games like this, but in Strider, I just didn't bother. They're not hard to get, usually, theyre just not worth it. I didn't want to waste my time.That being said, Strider is still a fun game. The action is frenetic and fun, but I'm honestly hesitant to recommend it. I actually felt like it wasted my time often when playing it. This is one of those many times I wish I could give a middling review score rather than the binary of "Yes" or "No". It's a good action game, but whenever it tries to be like a Metroid game, it just becomes boring. Buy at your own discretion.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20
												Pretty solid modernized version of Strider with Metroid-like level progression, though I wouldn't consider it a fully fledged metroidvania game since exploration aspect in this game is pretty pale. Takes around 7 hours to 100%. Navigation outside of main objectives isn't very fun and there aren't any real points of interest besides color-coded locked doors which usually hide a power-up or concept art unlock.Game itself is more combat oriented and that's where is shines. All animations are fast and don't cancel anything (e.g. you can jump, throw kunai and power up your slash at the same time), plus you get 4 different attack types that change how your combat moves behave, neither mode is a direct upgrade but instead they compliment each other (e.g. use reflective mode to reflect bullets while you run torwards the enemy, switch to magnetic mode and dash to stun them, and then switch to flame mode to finish the stunned enemy off). Most locked doors are opened by a dash so you don't have to pause while moving from area to area either. There are no pauses during movement or combat, it feels very streamlined and fast-paced.Visuals are nice and clean, have a nice style (e.g. some effects like dust or explosions look more hand-drawn than realistic), but nothing to write home about. Enemies telegraph their shots and projectiles are very easy to see. Bosses make great use of projectiles, something you would see in old arcade games. Bosses in this game are in general very fun and challenging, and urge you to move a lot, unlike some other modern metroidvania games (*cough*Shadow Complex*cough*).One thing that puzzles me is complete lack of facial animations during cutscenes. It's not noticable on Hiryu and some other characters that wear masks, but it looks very cheap on characters that don't.Some issues with the game: Game is locked at 60 fps. You can't remap keys in-game, but you can do so by editing config files. Non-XInput controllers are supported only through third-party means (x360ce). Controls during segments that have non-standard gravity are just plain bad both on keyboard and controller, but these segments are rare and it doesn't ruin them completely.

												- The controls arent very tight.- It feels like your constantly playing on the ice level from Super Mario.- Basic movement is a chore.- Climbing walls is very rigid and clunky.- The control scheme is very poor and cant be rebinded.- The fact that mobs can infinitely hit stun you to death because you need a charge attack to kill them is also a pain.- There is also a chance that when you fall into a pit and it respawns you that you will respawn inside a wall, and have no choice but restart the game.+ The boss fights are fun though, and this game is still alright, but overall it just gives me a headache.
